title: ‚Äòggstatsplot‚Äô : ‚Äòggplot2‚Äô Based Plots with Statistical Details
description:
We are pleased to invite you to our next meetup which will serve as an overview of the R Package ‚Äòggstatsplot‚Äô: ‚Äòggplot2‚Äô Based Plots with Statistical Details.

"ggstatsplot" is an extension of "ggplot2". It creates graphics with details from statistical tests included in the plots themselves. It is targeted primarily at behavioral sciences community to provide a one-line code to generate information-rich plots for statistical analysis of continuous (violin plots, scatterplots, histograms, dot plots, dot-and-whisker plots) or categorical (pie and bar charts) data. Currently, it supports only the most common types of statistical tests: parametric, nonparametric, robust, and bayesian versions of t-test/anova, correlation analyses, contingency table analysis, and regression analyses.

This wonderful R package is created by Indrajeet Patil. Come & join us to learn more about it https://github.com/IndrajeetPatil/ggstatsplot

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Indrajeet Patil https://sites.google.com/site/indrajeetspatilmorality/
Indrajeet Patil is a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Center for Humans and Machines, Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Berlin. He has a Ph.D. in cognitive neuroscience and specializes in investigating the psychological and neural basis of social judgment and decision-making. He is also an active R package developer and part of `easystats` team.

Date/Time : Tuesday, December 15, 2020 6PM -> 7PM (Tunisia time GMT+1)
Place : Google Meet

title: Statistical Analysis Tools of Complex Time-Series Data
description:
We are delighted to come together with you to host another online meetup : Statistical Analysis Tools of Complex Time-Series Data.

Date/Time : Friday, November 13, 2020 6:30PM -> 7:30PM (Tunisia time GMT+1)
Place : Zoom https://zoom.us/download

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited speaker : Pr. Fa√Øcel Chamroukhi
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Pr. Fa√Øcel Chamroukhi https://chamroukhi.com :
Fa√Øcel Chamroukhi is Professor of Statistics & Data Science in Caen, currently Adjunct Visiting Professor at La Trobe University and has been Assistant and Associate Professor of Computer Science and Machine Learning in Paris 13 and Toulon. He is broadly interested in the mathematical and algorithmic foundations of data science and AI, with a keen focus on modern statistics and machine learning. Common threads of his research include statistical modeling and inference, latent variable models, and learning in high-dimensional and large-scale scenario.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Abstract of the talk that he will be presenting :
Statistics are foundational to data analytics and learning systems to
infer relevant and interpretable knowledge from random representations of real-world scenarios. In this talk, he will present some contributions in scenarios involving complex heterogeneous time-series data. The developed model-based segmentation and clustering of time-series with underlying hidden structures will be illustrated via some applications in R software.

title: R4Bioinfo workshop : Introduction to Bioconductor Annotation Resources
description:
We are excited to invite you to the 2nd workshop of our R4Bioinfo series : Introduction to Bioconductor Annotation Resources.

During this workshop you'll learn about the different annotation packages provided by the Bioconductor project that can be used to incorporate additional information to results from high-throughput experiments.

Prerequisities :
Basic knowledge of R and Bioconductor https://bioconductor.org/

Date/Time : Wednesday, September 30th, 2020 5:30PM -> 7:30PM (Tunisia time GMT+1)
Place : Zoom https://zoom.us/download

Invited speaker :
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Dr. Martin Morgan: Director, Roswell Park R / Bioconductor Project.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Martin Morgan https://github.com/mtmorgan :
Dr. Morgan earned his undergraduate and Master's degrees in Botany at the University of Toronto. Dr. Morgan's PhD studies at the University of Chicago involved the evolutionary consequences of frequency-dependent selection, and of multilocus deleterious mutation.
Dr. Morgan spent 10 years as an Assistant and then Associate Professor at Washington State University, before joining the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in 2005. At the Hutch, Dr. Morgan worked on the Bioconductor project for the analysis and comprehension of high-throughput genomic data; he has led Bioconductor since 2008. Dr. Morgan moved to Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center in Buffalo, NY in 2015, where the Bioconductor project is now based.

title: Analysis of COVID-19 DATA with R
description:
We are excited to invite you to our next meetup : Analysis of COVID-19 data with R.

‚óæÔ∏è Date/Time : Wednesday, the 22nd of July 2020 6:00PM -> 7:30PM (Tunisia time GMT+1)
‚óæÔ∏è Place : Zoom (https://zoom.us/download)

Throughout the webinar, Dr. Dhafer Mallouche will be presenting his new website http://covid19data.website for monitoring the COVID-19 situation in the whole world. The website contains the Dashboard of the situation in all the countries with more than 1000 cases, in all the continents, the geographical territories, the countries by economic level (according to BM classification) as well as the different states of the US.
Dr. Mallouche gives also an estimate of the R(t) (reproduction number) during the last 60 days.
Dr. Mallouche's dashboard classifies as well the countries according to the COVID-19 situation based on 6 criteria : the R (t), the growth rate of confirmed, active and death cases and the number of cases per million inhabitants.

About Dr. Dhafer Mallouche :

He is a Professor of Statistics and Applied Mathematics at The University of Carthage. He earned his Ph.D. in Statistics and Applied
Mathematics from Paul Sabatier University in Toulouse, France, in October 1997, and a Master‚Äôs Degree in Applied Mathematics from the same university in June 1994. He started his academic professional as Assistant Professor in Sousse in Tunisia. In September 2003, Dr. Dhafer moved to the Higher Engineering School of Statistics of the University of Carthage. He was successively promoted to Associate-Professor in 2011, later to Professor in 2018. He had taught there several statistical and data science courses. He had supervised five Ph.D. in Applied Statistics. Dr. Dhafer has authored and co-authored more than 50 research papers in many topics related to applied statistics and mathematics. Dr. Dhafer was a Fulbright scholar at Stanford University and the University of Michigan. On several times he was a visiting scholar at Yale University and in prestigious colleges in Canada and France.

title: My Favorite ggplot2 Extension Packages
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about C√©dric'favorite ggplot2 extension Packages.

Date/Time: Wednesday, July, 8th 2021 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: C√©dric Scherer

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About C√©dric Scherer :

C√©dric is a trained researcher in ecology, evolution and nature conservation with a focus on computational biology. After his PhD, he combined his expertise in analysing and visualizing large data sets in R with his passion for design to create visualizations across all disciplines, purposes, and styles to become a freelance data visualization specialist. In his spare time, C√©dric is contributing regularly to the #TidyTuesday challenge and other data visualization contests and is hosting the #30DayChartChallenge together with Dominic Roy√© that took place for the first time this year.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:

Abstract: ggplot2 is a graphics library for R which comes with many geometries that allow you to build numerous and highly customized data visualizations. In this talk, I am going to present the most exciting extension packages to create various chart types within the ggplot2 framework but that are not part of the ggplot2 package itself. We are going to cover popular chart types such as bump graphs and ridgeline plots but also less common variants, for example stream graphs, moon plots, and geofacets.

title: Improve your Data Science pipelines with JavaScript
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about using JavaScript to improve data science pipelines.

Date/Time: Wednesday, June 23rd, 2021 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: John Coene

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About John Coene :
John Coene has worked for 5 years in tech companies in China, then, after 3 years at the World Economic Forum in Geneva, he set up his own company (https://opifex.org) He also works with Impact Lab Finance (https://impactlab-finance.com). He is the author of packages such as {echarts4r} https://echarts4r.john-coene.com/, {waiter} https://shiny.john-coene.com/waiter/, {packer} https://packer.john-coene.com/#/, (and more), as well as the book JavaScript for R forthcoming on CRC Press.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:

A brief introduction to using JavaScript with R. No prior knowledge of JavaScript is required.
R has been propelled into web browsers with package such as Rmarkdown and Shiny; combining JavaScript with R is now possible and immensely useful!
This aims to be an elevator pitch to demystify JavaScript and encourage R users to explore it: surprisingly little knowledge of the language brings amazing rewards.

title: A Little JS Goes a Long Way
description:
We are super excited to collaborate again with R-Ladies Tunis to host a new workshop, "A Little JS Goes a Long Way". The Amazing Maya Gans will give an overview of how javascript is used in R with a brief intro to Shiny app.

Thinking of looking at Shiny under the hood? Through using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript this talk will go through helpful use cases to empower you to start customising Shiny. Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R. You can host standalone apps on a webpage or embed them in R Markdown documents or build dashboards. It's very easy to write and it is not surprising to see Shiny apps popping up in all manner of applications including healthcare and medical applications.

WHO is this for?
- If you never worked with Shiny and want to understand how it is used?
- If you love Shiny app and want to understand more about how it's customised.
- Both beginners and experienced R users are welcome to join!

AGENDA
7:30‚Äì7:35 pm Who we are | Announcement about useR Conference 2021
7:35‚Äì8:25 pm A Little JS Goes a Long Way
8:25‚Äì8:30 pm Any Qs?

Our speaker, Maya Gans is an experienced R and JavaScript developer, who recently started applying those skills to the clinical trial space. After graduating with her Masters in Botany from the University of Wyoming, Maya interned at RStudio where she created a blocks based programming language called tidyblocks, as well as co-authoring ‚ÄúJavaScript for Data Science‚Äù. Currently, Maya writes R packages and Shiny applications to create dynamic, custom data visualisation and exploratory tools to aid in understanding complex data. Maya is also passionate about data science education and has given many talks and workshops about using and creating tools in R.

You can find out more about Maya Gans here:
Twitter: https://twitter.com/mayacelium
Website:https://maya.rbind.io/

Place: Zoom- https://zoom.us/download - The event will not be recorded.
We will send you the Zoom link & the passcode via email a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: R4Bioinfo Workshop: Introduction to Ensembl REST API - PART2
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a series of two workshops about Introduction to Ensembl REST API. This meeetup will cover the second part.

Date/Time: Friday, June 11th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place: ZOOM

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Dr. Aleena Mushtaq and Dr. Michal Szpak

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Aleena Mushtaq:
(https://www.linkedin.com/in/aleena-mushtaq-417bb6133/)
Aleena‚Äôs background is in Biomedical and Molecular sciences. She completed her PhD in 2020 at the University of East Anglia, UK. For her doctorate she studied the dynamic relationship of host and microbiota in the gut-liver axis in response to Western diets. She joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2021 and delivers training on Ensembl resources.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Michal Szpak:
(https://www.linkedin.com/in/michal-szpak/)
Michal took a degree in biology at the University of Warsaw, where he
studied ancient DNA. He subsequently moved to bioinformatics and
explored human genetic variation across different ethnicities in his
master‚Äôs degree research at the Center for Public Health Genomics,
university of Virginia. He joined the human evolution team at the
Wellcome Sanger Institute in 2012 and received his PhD in human
population genetics from University of Cambridge. His doctoral and
postdoctoral work at the Sanger focused on positive selection and
genetic adaptations in humans. He joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2019 and continues to deliver Ensembl training worldwide.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
This workshop will be divided into two parts. During these two parts you'll learn about:
- Introduction to REST API
- Making requests with R
- Find an endpoint which you can use to lookup information about a gene using its symbol
- Create a URL to find information about a gene
- Expand your results to include information about transcripts
- Convert a fromJSON module used to pull out the data to a dataframe
- Get a sequence in FASTA
- Gene trees and homologues in various formats
- Alignments
- Get all variants that are associated with a phenotype and print the needed information about these variants
- Linking endpoints together
- Using POST to run a query with multiple inputs at once

The invited trainers will go over these materials (http://training.ensembl.org/events/2021/2021-06-04-RLadiesREST_June) during the training session.

By the end of this series, you will be able to make requests with R through Ensembl REST API.

https://tinyurl.com/d7kvxby

We will send you the ZOOM link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Github for collaboration
description:
Details
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about Using Github for collaboration.

Date/Time: Thursday, June 10th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Dr. Lisa Lendway

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Lisa Lendway :
Dr. Lisa Lendway teaches statistics and data science at Macalester College, a small liberal arts college for undergraduates in St. Paul, MN USA. She is passionate about applying statistics to any subject matter and enjoys helping people see the benefits of using statistical analysis and data visualization to answer questions. Outside of statistics, Lisa enjoys spending time with her two daughters, cycling with her husband, making old things new, and playing in her jungle garden. She even went so far as to record her harvest data last year and turn it into an R package: https://github.com/llendway/gardenR

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
In this MeetUp, we'll talk about using Git and GitHub with R projects in the RStudio IDE. This will be a hands-on talk with plenty of opportunity to interact. To get the most out of the meeting, it is recommended that you do a few steps before the meeting: see the "What you should already know" section of my https://lisalendway.netlify.app/posts/2021-02-24-gitinrstudio/ blog post to get your GitHub account set up and to connect it with RStudio. First, we will review how to create our own projects and practice committing, pushing, and creating branches. Then, we will practice adding collaborators where we will clone a repo and deal with a merge conflict. Next, we'll talk about pull requests and practice doing them! Lastly, I'll talk about a couple ways you can undo things you didn't mean to do in Git. I am by no means a Git or GitHub pro. So along the way, I'll probably make some mistakes, but there's no better way to learn, right?

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form üëâ
https://tinyurl.com/2k88f8nd

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: A quick flight to the edge of the tidyverse
description:
We are very excited to come together with you to host another online meetup. We are collaborating with R-Ladies Tunis to host the second part of the exceptional online session that introduces codes and R functions using cute, fuzzy creatures by the amazing Allison Horst.

The workshop " Explore tidyverse with the funny MonsteRs - part 2" by Allison Horst will help you to picture the functions in your code as cute, fuzzy monsters, and your data as colorful gems. This workshop will make it easier than ever to understand complicated functions in R and create awesome plots.

Our speaker, Allison Horst is an Assistant Teaching Professor at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management, UC Santa Barbara, where she teaches environmental data science, statistics, math, and presentation skills courses. She is also the co-founder of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, founder, and organizer of the UCSB TidyTuesday coding club, and was RStudio's first Artist-in-Residence from 2019 - 2020. Her academic background is in engineering (BS Chemical Engineering, MS Mechanical Engineering) and environmental science (PhD Environmental Science and Management). When she isn't coding or drawing, she enjoys hiking and fly-fishing with her partner Greg and their dog Teddy.

You can find out more about Allison Horst here: https://allisonhorst.github.io/
https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations

title: Introduce yourself online with blogdown & Hugo Ap√©ro
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about Using blogdown & Hugo Ap√©ro to create your personal website.

Date/Time: Wednesday, May 26th, 2021 from 7 PM to 9 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Dr. Alison Hill

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Alison Hill :
Alison Hill is a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and an award-winning educator. Currently, Dr. Hill works to make data science communication easier and more delightful using RStudio‚Äôs open-source toolchain. Previously, Alison was an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Oregon Health & Science University. Her research focused on health-related applications of Natural Language Processing-based methods, and was funded by the National Institutes of Health, the Oregon Clinical and Translational Research Institute, and Autism Speaks. She has written numerous scientific publications on autism and neurodevelopmental disorders and has presented research at over 25 international conferences. Alison has also taught statistics and data science for over 10 years; most recently, she has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. She is also an international keynote speaker (https://alison.rbind.io/talks), co-developer of the palmerpenguins (https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/), distill (https://rstudio.github.io/distill/), and blogdown (https://pkgs.rstudio.com/blogdown) R packages, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown (https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/).

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
‚ÄúYou should have a website!‚Äù You may have heard this one before, or even said it yourself. In this workshop, you‚Äôll learn how to build and customize a website from the comfort of the RStudio IDE with R Markdown. We'll use the blogdown package and the Hugo Ap√©ro theme to build and deploy a personal website. We‚Äôll cover basic website care and feeding like using R Markdown to create content, how to use GitHub for version control and Netlify for publishing, and how to use the latest upgrades to the blogdown R package to keep your site up and running.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Prerequisites

You'll get the most out of this workshop if you do the pre-work ahead of time. Please follow the instructions here: https://iyo-rstudio-global.netlify.app/collection/prework/.

title: A Tidy Transcriptomics introduction to bulk and scRNA sequencing analyses
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a new workshop which will serve as a Tidy Transcriptomics introduction to bulk and scRNA sequencing analyses.

Date/Time: Saturday, April 9, 2021 from 10 AM to 12:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom https://zoom.us/download

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainers: Dr. Stefano Mangiola and Dr. Maria Doyle

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Stefano Mangiola:
Dr. Stefano Mangiola is currently a Postdoctoral researcher in the laboratory of Prof. Tony Papenfuss. His background spans from biotechnology to bioinformatics and biostatistics. His research focuses on prostate and breast tumour microenvironment, the development of statistical model for the analysis of RNA sequencing data, and data analysis and visualisation interfaces.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Maria Doyle:
Dr. Maria Doyle is the Application and Training Specialist for Research Computing at the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre in Melbourne, Australia. She has a PhD in Molecular Biology and currently works in bioinformatics and data science education and training. She is passionate about supporting researchers, reproducible research, open source and tidy data.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:

This workshop will present how to perform analysis of RNA sequencing data following the tidy data paradigm (Wickham and others 2014). The tidy data paradigm provides a standard way to organise data values within a dataset, where each variable is a column, each observation is a row, and data is manipulated using an easy-to-understand vocabulary. Most importantly, the data structure remains consistent across manipulation and analysis functions.
This can be achieved for RNA sequencing data with the tidybulk, tidyHeatmap (Mangiola and Papenfuss 2020) and tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) packages. The tidybulk package provides a tidy data structure and a modular framework for bulk transcriptional analyses. tidyHeatmap provides a tidy implementation of ComplexHeatmap. These packages are part of the tidytranscriptomics suite that introduces a tidy approach to RNA sequencing data representation and analysis. The last section of the workshop will be focused on the analysis of single cell data in a tidy fashion with the packages tidySCE and tidyseurat.

The topics presented in this workshop will be:

‚ñ™Ô∏è Data exploration
‚ñ™Ô∏è Data dimensionality reduction and clustering
‚ñ™Ô∏è Differential gene expression analysis
‚ñ™Ô∏è Data visualisation

title: R4Bioinfo workshop: Epidemiology for Bioinformaticians
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a new workshop about Epidemiology for Bioinformaticians.

Date/Time: Friday, March 26, 2021 from 5:30 PM to 7:45 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom https://zoom.us/download

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Chloe Mirzayi
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Chloe Mirzayi:
Chloe Mirzayi, MPH is a doctoral candidate in Epidemiology at the City University of New York (CUNY) Graduate School of Public Health and Health Policy and Data Scientist at the CUNY Institute for Implementation Science in Population Health (ISPH). She has experience designing, implementing, and maintaining data collection, management, and curation tools on a variety of projects ranging from large national cohort studies to RCTs in topics related to COVID-19, microbiome, HIV, substance use, and mental health. Her own research interests are focused on the role of the microbiome on human health, causal inference in microbiome research, and improving the epidemiological rigor of health and bioinformatics research.
Chloe's dissertation research will focus on the impact of antibiotics on the human gut microbiome. Her mentor and dissertation committee chair is CUNY ISPH Investigator Dr. Levi Waldron.

‚û°Ô∏è About the workshop:
Concepts of causal inference in epidemiology have important ramifications for studies across bioinformatics and other fields of health research. In this workshop, Chloe Mirzayi will introduce basic concepts of epidemiology, study design, and causal inference for bioinformaticians. Emphasis is placed on addressing bias and confounding as common threats to assessing a causal pathway in a variety of study design types and when using common forms of analyses such as GWAS and survival analysis. Workshop participants will have the opportunity to create their own structural causal models (DAGs) and use this model to determine how to assess an estimated causal effect. Examples using DESeq2, edgeR, and limma will be used to show how multivariable models can be fitted depending on the hypothesized causal relationship.

title: Integrating gene expression and DNA-binding data using R/Bioconductor
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a new workshop which will serve as an overview of the integrating gene expression and DNA-binding data using R/Bioconductor.

Date/Time : Saturday, February 27, 2021 from 2 PM to 4:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place : Zoom https://zoom.us/download

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer : Dr. Mahmoud Shaaban
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Mahmoud Shaaban :
Dr. Mahmoud Shaaban graduated from medical school, Cairo University, Egypt, in 2015. He received his master's and PhD from Gyeongsang National University, Korea, in 2021, where he studied the role of autophagy in development and disease. He used R/Bioconductor to analyze gene expression and transcription data from mice models. He wrote open-source R packages to distribute the data, methods, and code of my research

Description of the workshop :
Researchers use ChIP binding data to identify potential transcription factor binding sites. They use gene expression data from sequencing or microarrays to quantify the effect of the factor over-expression or knockdown on its targets. The integration of the binding and expression data therefore can be used to improve the understanding of a transcription factor function. In this workshop, I present a complete workflow for integrating the gene expression (microarray/RNA-seq) and DNA-binding data (ChIP-seq) to predict the combined function of two transcription factors using R/Bioconductor. The example we will be using in the workshop is from real datasets of two functionally and evolutionary related transcription factors YY1 and YY2 in HeLa cells. We will try to identify the factor-specific and the shared targets of the factors in this particular cell line. Then we will use a technique find out the aggregate functions of the factors on their individual (inducer or repressor) and common targets (cooperative or competitive).

More details about the workshop are provided through this link https://mahshaaban.github.io/IntegratingDataBioc/

description:
We are pleased to invite you to our next meetup : Using R and a Raspberry Pi to automate social media data collection.

Date/Time : Saturday, February 20, 2021 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place : Zoom https://zoom.us/download

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited speaker : Friedrike Preu
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Friedrike Preu :
Frie is a data4gooder, data scientist and IT person. Right now, she is working full-time for Data4Good network CorrelAid for which she has been volunteering since its beginnings in 2015. There, she is responsible for the coordination of the skilled-volunteering data science projects which are at the core of CorrelAid‚Äôs work. In addition, she organizes educational events and workshops.
Frie has a background in social science but transitioned to data science after her Bachelor‚Äôs degree and worked in IT consulting for two years. She loves to juggle and visualize data in R and likes to automate all kinds of things using her other programming skills.

Abstract :
Often when collecting data, we want to do so on a recurring basis. But how? Especially when starting out with (R) programming, this can be a complex challenge as sentences like "just set up a EC2 instance" are thrown at you without much context. In my talk, I will take you along my personal learning journey over the course of the past 3.5 years and three solution approaches: from a hacky R script on a Raspberry Pi (a mini computer) to a Python-solution in "the cloud" back to an improved R/Raspberry Pi version. In the process, I'll cycle back to fundamental tools/concepts like CRON that are central to automation.

title: RNA-seq analysis is easy as 1-2-3 with limma, Glimma and edgeR
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a workshop which will cover the RNA-seq analysis.

The ability to easily and efficiently analyse RNA-sequencing data is a key strength of the Bioconductor project. Starting with counts summarised at the gene-level, a typical analysis involves pre-processing, exploratory data analysis, differential expression testing and pathway analysis with the results obtained informing future experiments and validation studies. In this workflow article, we analyse RNA-sequencing data from the mouse mammary gland, demonstrating use of the popular edgeR package to import, organise, filter and normalise the data, followed by the limma package with its voom method, linear modelling and empirical Bayes moderation to assess differential expression and perform gene set testing. This pipeline is further enhanced by the Glimma package which enables interactive exploration of the results so that individual samples and genes can be examined by the user. The complete analysis offered by these three packages highlights the ease with which researchers can turn the raw counts from an RNA-sequencing experiment into biological insights using Bioconductor (https://f1000research.com/articles/5-1408).

Date/Time : Februrary 6th, 2021 from 10:00 AM to 12:15 PM GMT+1
Place : Zoom https://zoom.us/download

Xueyi Dong is a PhD candidate at Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, Melbourne, Australia. She loves to share her experiences with RNA-seq data analysis. Xueyi has translated the analysis workflow package RNAseq123 (https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/workflows/html/RNAseq123.html) into Mandarin, and she has taught the workshop on different events using both English and Mandarin.

title: Getting the most out of text - Using supervised & unsupervised approaches in NLP
description:
We're starting the year with an exceptional online session, and collaborating with the Facebook Developer Circles, a network of developers in Tunis and its surroundings who are interested in building on the Facebook platform to interact and collaborate with other developers who share similar interests https://www.facebook.com/groups/DevCTunis

We are excited to welcome you during a workshop which aims to get the most out of text -- Using supervised and unsupervised approaches in NLP

Text data provides an oasis of information for both researchers and non-researchers alike to explore. Natural Language Processing (NLP) helps to make sense of this data type.

The talk will give you a smooth introduction to the quanteda #R package (https://quanteda.io/).

Our speaker, Cosima will also showcase some visualizations of the results as well as supervised and unsupervised approaches in NLP.

Date/Time : Saturday, January 30, 2021 5PM - 7PM (Tunisia time GMT+1)
Place : Facebook Live and Zoom https://zoom.us/download

We will be live on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/groups/DevCTunis Otherwise, you might fill out this Google form üëâ https://tinyurl.com/y3a9ac3l in order to receive the Zoom link and the passcode and so that you are able to have a live discussion with our guest speaker.

We will send you the Zoom link & the passcode via email a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.

Speaker :

Cosima Meyer (cosimameyer.rbind.io) is a computational conflict researcher, PhD candidate at the University of Mannheim, Germany, and a data lover.
When she is not blogging about data science-related content on Methods Bites (https://bit.ly/methods-bites), Cosima maintains the R package overviewR (https://bit.ly/overviewR).

We look forward to welcoming you !

title: Web Scraping in R
description:
R-Ladies Tunis and ESSAI Junior Entreprise are partnering up and are organizing a training session about Web Scraping in R.

We will be hosting Riva Quiroga and Dr. Mohamed El Fodil Ihaddaden.

Riva Quiroga will show us an example of creating a function to scrape many pages of a website, and another about scraping tables using the R package rvest. She will also showcase how to use RegEx to clean the data. There will be a live coding under the programming language R.

Dr. Mohamed El Fodil Ihaddaden will introduce his R package "ralger" to us. This package aims to make it easier to scrape a website https://github.com/feddelegrand7/ralger

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Riva Quiroga https://rivaquiroga.cl/
Riva Quiroga is a linguist currently pursuing a PhD in that area, and an editor at Programming Historian, a Digital Humanities open access journal that publishes novice-friendly, peer-reviewed tutorials that help humanists learn a wide range of digital tools, techniques, and workflows to facilitate research and teaching.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Mohamed El Fodil Ihaddaden https://ihaddadenfodil.com/
Dr. Mohamed has a PhD in Economics and Msc in Statistics and Applied Economics. He's an R developer, and RStudio Certified Instructor. Throughout his PhD thesis, he has been working mainly on the application of a non-parametric technique called Data Envelopment Analysis in order to improve Algerian public banks‚Äô performance. Furthermore, he is also interested in implementing machine learning algorithms to solve complex real world issues.

title: Tidying Up Messy Data
description:
We are pleased to invite you to our next meetup : Tidying Up Messy Data.

Data cleaning has always been a challenging task for every data scientist. Tidy Data is a way of structuring datasets to facilitate analysis. During the workship, you will learn about how to organize messy datasets in an efficient manner. The workshop will cover a live coding.

We will be hosting Dr. Bruno Grande.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Bruno Grande https://www.linkedin.com/in/brunograndephd/ Dr. Bruno Grande (he/him) has been training others in the ways of modern R programming since 2015. With a PhD in bioinformatics, he learned (the hard way) how to leverage the tidyverse toolbox to efficiently transform, analyze, and visualize data ranging from messy to tidy. As a Carpentries- and RStudio-certified trainer, he wishes to empower the next generation of researchers and professionals with the same data science skills that continue to bolster his career. He‚Äôs currently promoting and implementing best practices in open science as a Bioinformatics Engineer at Sage Bionetworks in Seattle, WA.

title: Creating Your Own R Package
description:
## **Details**

We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about Creating Your Own R Package by Wolf Riepl .
Date/Time: Wednesday, March, 23rd 2022 from 7 PM to 8 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Wolf Riepl
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Wolf Riepl :
Wolf Riepl is a Radio and TV technician and a Sociologist by training. At university he worked with SPSS and Stata. His first contact to R came in 2007, when he worked for a small company that thought about avoiding the SPSS licence fees. After a 2-day-workshop he vowed to never open the R software again. It took seven years to start the next attempt. Since late 2014, Wolf has been working his way into R and never looked back. He now focuses on workshops and trainings, mostly online since 2020 after many in-person-workshops since 2017.
https://www.linkedin.com/in/wolfriepl/
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the talk:
What may sound like a very advanced topic is actually much easier than you may think! And it feels really good to have created a package.
What we'll do:
\- Create our first package in RStudio in 2 minutes
\- Create a package with our own function\, and document the function to get a regular help page for it
Outlook and discussion:
\- Adding data to a package \(or creating a pure data package\) and documenting it
\- Adding vignettes to a package: a more general form of documentation compared to the more specific function documentation \- Setting up automated testing using testthat
Make sure to join us!

title: Speed up your spreadsheet reports with R
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about Speed up your spreadsheet reports with R .
Date/Time: Wednesday, March, 16th 2022 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Larry Lathrop
‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Larry Lathrop:
Larry Lathrop is just a dad of 5 who loves data almost as much as he loves his family and their slobbery St Bernard. Larry is the head of analytics for OWLLytics with a passion for data visualizations. Larry enjoys traveling the world and currently lives in Valencia Spain.

Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/in/larry-lathrop/

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the talk:

Love them or hate them, reports can take a long time to create. Instead of spending most of your time creating your reports, just streamline the process. Let's use R to tackle this problem! Don't worry, if your audience lives and swears by a spreadsheet, you can still use R. In this talk, we will demonstrate a simple and easy way you can use R to automate most of your reports. After implementing these simple techniques, you will be able to spend more time changing the world and less time on reports. Or if you prefer (like myself) spend more time savoring your coffee.

title: When to stop using Excel and start using R
description:
Details

Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Nathan Stephens

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Nathan Stephens:
Nathan is a Senior Manager for Developer Relations at NVIDIA. His background is in analytic solutions and consulting.
He has experience building data science teams, architecting analytic
infrastructure, and delivering innovative data products. He is a longtime advocate foroperationalizing data science using open-source software. He is a longtime user of R.
Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/in/nwstephens/

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the talk:
Spreadsheets are incredibly useful, especially when your data are small. But what happens when your data become too large and too complex for Excel? When that happens, your workbook can be difficult to maintain, and the integrity of your data may be compromised. In this
webinar, we will demonstrate the benefits of using the R programming language when Excel gets overloaded.
What do we mean by ‚Äútoo large‚Äù?
‚óè Too many rows - 1,048,576
‚óè Too many columns - 16,384
‚óè Too many workbooks - 255
What do we mean by "too complex‚Äù?
‚óè Too many data sources
‚óè Too many complex functions
‚óè Too much VBA code and user interactivity

title: Time series analysis in R
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about time series in R.

Date/Time: Wednesday, Junuary, 26th 2022 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Veerle van Leemput

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Veerle van Leemput :

Veerle van Leemput (https://www.linkedin.com/in/veerlevanleemput/) is an entrepreneur and Data Scientist who gets excited about data and programming. She is Managing Director and Head of Data Science at Analytic Health, a UK-based company that develops intelligent and accessible technology which gives organisations the tools they need to accelerate innovation in healthcare. She is an R developer with a Master‚Äôs Degree in Data Science and multiple years of experience in the pharmaceutical market. Besides programming in R and making R Shiny applications, she also develops multiple web applications for healthcare organisations using Vue.js and Node at Analytic Health.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the talk:

When you think about anything to do with machine learning, many people instantly think of Python. And that‚Äôs because there are great packages for Python like scikit-learn that make Python an excellent choice to make models and solve machine learning problems. But did you know that R offers many machine learning packages as well? During this meetup, Veerle will tell more about making demand forecasts specifically. She will go into detail about how they‚Äôre using R to do time series analysis and make demand forecasts for medicine supply at Analytic Health. If you want to learn more about the basics of doing a proper time series analysis, the Prophet algorithm developed by Facebook, and other relevant packages and tools to model your time series in R, make sure to join us!

Loan will be presenting her book R Shiny Applications in Finance, Medicine, Pharma and Education Industry

About this book :
R Shiny Application is a structure for making web applications utilizing R code. It is planned fundamentally considering information researchers, and keeping that in mind, you can make pretty confounded Shiny applications with no knowledge about HTML, CSS, or JavaScript. Then again, Shiny doesn‚Äôt restrict you to making insignificant or pre-assembled applications: its UI segments can be handily modified or expanded, and its worker utilizes responsive programming to allow you to make any sort of back-end rationale you need. R Shiny is intended to feel mystically simple when you‚Äôre beginning, but then the further you get into how it functions, the more you understand it‚Äôs worked out of broad structure obstructs that have solid programming standards behind them.
R Shiny Application is utilized in nearly however many specialties and ventures as R itself is. It‚Äôs utilized in scholarly world as a showing device for measurable ideas, an approach to get students camped up for figuring out how to compose code, a sensational mode for flaunting novel factual techniques or models.
